articles.headline: U.S.-Europe Team Beats Out Boeing on Big Contract
articles.snippet: A $40 billion Air Force contract for aerial refueling tankers is now partly in the hands of a foreign company.
articles.abstract: A $40 billion Air Force contract for aerial refueling tankers is now partly in the hands of a foreign company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Air Force, in a stunning upset against the Boeing Company, awarded a $40 billion contract for aerial refueling tankers on Friday to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus, putting a critical military contract partly into the hands of a foreign company.

articles.headline: Prince Harry and the Secret Kept by Fleet Street
articles.snippet: Despite London’s rabid tabloid culture, journalists kept quiet for 10 weeks about his deployment to Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Despite London’s rabid tabloid culture, journalists kept quiet for 10 weeks about his deployment to Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every morning for 10 weeks, Bob Satchwell typed the words “Prince Harry” and “Afghanistan” into Google, and every morning, the top result was the same: “Prince Harry Is Forbidden To Fight Alongside Soldiers In Afghanistan.”
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Sarah Lyall

articles.headline: A C.E.O. Sells the Store
articles.snippet: Millard S. Drexler, the chief executive of J. Crew, visited a Madewell store looking for customers he could talk to.
articles.abstract: Millard S. Drexler, the chief executive of J. Crew, visited a Madewell store looking for customers he could talk to.
articles.lead_paragraph: Women’s suits. Mickey Drexler has women’s suits on the brain.

articles.headline: Obama Walks a Difficult Path as He Courts Jewish Voters
articles.snippet: The senator faces challenges as he tries to strengthen support in a cornerstone of the Democratic base.
articles.abstract: The senator faces challenges as he tries to strengthen support in a cornerstone of the Democratic base.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he battles for the Democratic nomination, Senator Barack Obama is trying to strengthen his support among Jewish voters and in doing so, is navigating one of the more treacherous paths of Democratic politics.

articles.headline: Buffett’s State of the World: There’s Folly in Wonderland
articles.snippet: Warren Buffett’s annual letter to shareholders, which was released Friday, has become something of a business institution, with the hope that he will shed light on his investments.
articles.abstract: Warren Buffett’s annual letter to shareholders, which was released Friday, has become something of a business institution, with the hope that he will shed light on his investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett disclosed Friday that he had earned profits for shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway by speculating in the Brazilian currency, the real, and by buying a large stake in a French pharmaceutical company, Sanofi-Aventis.

articles.headline: Markets Fall on Drumbeat of Grim Reports
articles.snippet: The Standard and Poor’s 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average capped their worst four months since 2002.
articles.abstract: The Standard and Poor’s 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average capped their worst four months since 2002.
articles.lead_paragraph: An outpouring of negative economic and financial reports soured the mood on Wall Street Friday as banks and other lenders further tightened credit in their struggle to contain damage from losses on mortgages, business loans and related debt.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: The Art of the Save, for Goalie and Investor
articles.snippet: When it comes to choosing what to do, sometimes the best thing is nothing.
articles.abstract: When it comes to choosing what to do, sometimes the best thing is nothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to choosing what to do, sometimes the best thing is nothing.

articles.headline: Preserving a Forest and a Philosophy
articles.snippet: A Costa Rican trek served as a metaphor for the difficulty many executives are having as they transition from niche marketers to big-business men.
articles.abstract: A Costa Rican trek served as a metaphor for the difficulty many executives are having as they transition from niche marketers to big-business men.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEVERDE, Costa Rica  A group of pioneers in the “green business” were getting back to their roots with a two-day hike through a pristine rain forest in Costa Rica when they hit Fer-de-lance Hill.

articles.headline: In Parts of U.S., Foreclosures Top Sales
articles.snippet: Mortgage foreclosure notices are going out so fast that in some states the number of new foreclosure proceedings each month is greater than the number of homes sold that month.
articles.abstract: Mortgage foreclosure notices are going out so fast that in some states the number of new foreclosure proceedings each month is greater than the number of homes sold that month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage foreclosure notices are going out so fast that in some states the number of new foreclosure proceedings each month is greater than the number of homes sold that month.

articles.headline: Now Comes the Tough Part in Russia
articles.snippet: Two new works look at Russia’s economic progress as Dmitri A. Medvedev succeeds Vladimir Putin in the presidency.
articles.abstract: Two new works look at Russia’s economic progress as Dmitri A. Medvedev succeeds Vladimir Putin in the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: DMITRI A. MEDVEDEV will be anointed president of Russia today thanks to the political handiwork of Vladimir V. Putin. But maybe the real winner is economic globalization.

articles.headline: The Buck Has Stopped
articles.snippet: In spite of the Federal Reserve’s efforts to fight off a recession, a consumer-led recession has already begun.
articles.abstract: In spite of the Federal Reserve’s efforts to fight off a recession, a consumer-led recession has already begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEN S. BERNANKE, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress last week that fighting off a possible recession in the United States was Job 1 for his crew. But a consumer-led recession has already begun, according to a new index that reflects how much money Americans can actually spend right now.

articles.headline: Tapping Into Homes Can Be Pitfall for the Elderly
articles.snippet: Reverse mortgages have boomed, but many consumers complain of unethical and high-pressure sales tactics.
articles.abstract: Reverse mortgages have boomed, but many consumers complain of unethical and high-pressure sales tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Erika Baker was 67 years old, divorced and worried about her job when a saleswoman showed up at her door in late 2006.

articles.headline: Is a Lean Economy Turning Mean?
articles.snippet: Workers are getting fewer hours, and those without jobs are staying unemployed longer or accepting lower pay.
articles.abstract: Workers are getting fewer hours, and those without jobs are staying unemployed longer or accepting lower pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif.  NICOLE FLENNAUGH has a college degree, office experience and the modest expectation that, somewhere in this city on the eastern lip of San Francisco Bay, someone will want to hire her.

articles.headline: Scorched-Earth Strategy Returns to Darfur
articles.snippet: Aid workers, diplomats and analysts say the fighting is entering a new and deadly phase as efforts to find a negotiated peace founder.
articles.abstract: Aid workers, diplomats and analysts say the fighting is entering a new and deadly phase as efforts to find a negotiated peace founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: SULEIA, Sudan  The janjaweed are back.

articles.headline: Online Scrabble Craze Leaves Game Sellers at Loss for Words
articles.snippet: The companies that own the rights to the Scrabble board game say a popular online knockoff is piracy.
articles.abstract: The companies that own the rights to the Scrabble board game say a popular online knockoff is piracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  The latest bane of office productivity is Scrabulous, a virtual knockoff of the Scrabble board game, with over 700,000 players a day and nearly three million registered users.

articles.headline: U.S. Plan Widens Role in Training Pakistani Forces in Qaeda Battle
articles.snippet: A plan would send U.S. trainers to work with a paramilitary force that is the vanguard in the fight against Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: A plan would send U.S. trainers to work with a paramilitary force that is the vanguard in the fight against Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States military is developing a plan to send about 100 American trainers to work with a Pakistani paramilitary force that is the vanguard in the fight against Al Qaeda and other extremist groups in Pakistan’s restive tribal areas, American military officials said.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Spending Heavily, Obama Attempts Knockout Blow
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama is leveraging his huge financial edge over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the potentially decisive Texas and Ohio contests.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama is leveraging his huge financial edge over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the potentially decisive Texas and Ohio contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Taking advantage of his financial edge, Senator Barack Obama is buying large amounts of advertising and building extensive get-out-the-vote operations in an effort to end Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s candidacy with twin defeats Tuesday in Ohio and Texas.

articles.headline: As Economy Lags in U.S., Oil Nations Rethink Cuts
articles.snippet: With high oil prices weighing on a struggling economy, OPEC is likely to keep output unchanged when its members meet Wednesday.
articles.abstract: With high oil prices weighing on a struggling economy, OPEC is likely to keep output unchanged when its members meet Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: With high oil prices weighing on a struggling economy, the OPEC oil cartel is reconsidering its plans to cut production, a move that could push prices above their current record levels. Instead, OPEC is likely to keep output unchanged when its members meet Wednesday.

articles.headline: States and Cities Start Rebelling on Bond Ratings
articles.snippet: Some states and cities say Wall Street ratings firms assign municipal borrowers inappropriately low credit scores.
articles.abstract: Some states and cities say Wall Street ratings firms assign municipal borrowers inappropriately low credit scores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does Wall Street underrate Main Street?
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: In Ohio, Tense Race Hinges on Grass-Roots Organizers
articles.snippet: The street-by-street ground war will determine the outcome of the Democratic primary.
articles.abstract: The street-by-street ground war will determine the outcome of the Democratic primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND  The callers, volunteers at a Clinton campaign field office here, had some exciting news last week for the randomly dialed Democrats on the other end of the line. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York was appearing at a high school in Toledo the next day, and there was still plenty of room for cheering spectators.

articles.headline: In Texas, Clinton’s Veterans Test Obama’s Rookies
articles.snippet: The Clinton campaign has relied on deep connections, while the Obama campaign seems remarkably self-generating.
articles.abstract: The Clinton campaign has relied on deep connections, while the Obama campaign seems remarkably self-generating.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEXARKANA, Tex.  Just 32 miles from a place called Hope, this small working-class city at the Texas and Arkansas border is “Clinton country,” as people here frequently and firmly remind you.

articles.headline: Hollywood, Silicon Valley and AT&T? It’s a Deal
articles.snippet: The William Morris Agency is joining Silicon Valley venture capital firms Accel Partners and Venrock to invest in digital media start-up companies.
articles.abstract: The William Morris Agency is joining Silicon Valley venture capital firms Accel Partners and Venrock to invest in digital media start-up companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood and Silicon Valley have something of a Mars/Venus problem: the two sides are talking but they don’t speak each other’s language. A new venture involving a phone company may just add Pluto into the mix.

articles.headline: After Suicide, Blog Insults Are Debated
articles.snippet: Visitors to AgencySpy and AdScam, two sharp-tongued advertising industry blogs, posted comments blaming the sites for contributing to ad executive Paul Tilley’s suicide.
articles.abstract: Visitors to AgencySpy and AdScam, two sharp-tongued advertising industry blogs, posted comments blaming the sites for contributing to ad executive Paul Tilley’s suicide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Advertising blogs churn out some of the Web’s more scathing, and personal, vitriol. Last week, the bloggers absorbed some body blows of their own.

articles.headline: Meeting on Arms Data Reignites Iran Debate
articles.snippet: The chief U.N. nuclear inspector laid out evidence in a meeting last Monday that he said raised new questions about whether Iran had tried to design an atom bomb.
articles.abstract: The chief U.N. nuclear inspector laid out evidence in a meeting last Monday that he said raised new questions about whether Iran had tried to design an atom bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Monday, the chief United Nations nuclear inspector gathered ambassadors and experts from dozens of nations in a boardroom high above the Danube in Vienna and laid out a trove of evidence that he said raised new questions about whether Iran had tried to design an atom bomb.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Very Model of a Modern Media Mogul
articles.snippet: Among the Hollywood developers scrambling to create original Internet programs, Michael Eisner is one of the very few who can claim early success.
articles.abstract: Among the Hollywood developers scrambling to create original Internet programs, Michael Eisner is one of the very few who can claim early success.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When Michael D. Eisner left the Walt Disney Company in 2005 and set about remaking himself in new media, investing in a video-sharing Web site and starting a digital studio, some people in Hollywood snickered. Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesn’t know when to leave the stage.

articles.headline: Gaza Pitfalls in Every Path
articles.snippet: President Bush’s peace plan has been to prop up President Mahmoud Abbas, but Hamas can still subvert progress.
articles.abstract: President Bush’s peace plan has been to prop up President Mahmoud Abbas, but Hamas can still subvert progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ever since the militant Islamist organization Hamas took over Gaza eight months ago, President Bush’s peace plan for the Middle East has been to prop up the more moderate Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in the hopes that Palestinians would rally behind him as man who could bring them statehood and make Hamas irrelevant.

articles.headline: In Oscars, No Country for Hit Films
articles.snippet: It’s no longer about blockbusters and crowd-pleasers.
articles.abstract: It’s no longer about blockbusters and crowd-pleasers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Governor’s Ball, the gilded post-Oscar fete, many of the evening’s winners swanned about with statues in one hand and glasses of Champagne in the other, while the losers washed down what was left of the evening with stronger spirits.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Tastemakers Write Unfiltered Blog
articles.snippet: On a new blog, Wal-Mart is encouraging employees to be frank, and even critical, about products the chain carries.
articles.abstract: On a new blog, Wal-Mart is encouraging employees to be frank, and even critical, about products the chain carries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft is one of Wal-Mart’s biggest suppliers. But that did not stop the Wal-Mart employee in charge of buying computers from panning Microsoft’s newest operating system, Vista.
